content.div:
Whitney Houston's funeral Saturday will be "invitation only." This much we learned earlier this week. Aretha Franklin is expected to attend the noon-hour service -- as is Chaka Khan, Jennifer Hudson, Ray J, Brandy, L.A. Reid and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, according to reports. Houston's Bodyguard costar, Kevin Costner, is also expected to speak at the service, reports People.

As for the late singer's ex-husband, Bobby Brown, it seems he'll be there, too. Reports out of ABC News and Forbes are refuting TMZ's suggestion that the New Edition singer was banned from the service by Houston's family, and as Brown himself told ABC News, he is currently with his and Houston's daughter, 18-year-old Bobbi Kristina.

All told, CNN reports 1,500 people will be gathered inside Newark's New Hope Baptist Church, where Houston sang at as a girl.

But there will be countless more watching. The service will be broadcast online and on TV, Houston's publicist told CNN. (Associated Press will have a camera inside the funeral, streaming the service here. Tune in Saturday at noon.) And for the fans who've been keeping vigil outside the church, the New York Daily News reports that plans are underway to erect TV screens for those gathered outside. It'll be the next best thing to a public memorial, something which members of the diva's family have chosen to avoid.

The family didn't "want to have a parade," Rev. Marvin L. Winans, a Grammy-winning gospel singer and the pastor set to preside over Houston's funeral, told CNN's Anderson Cooper.

"I don't think knowing Cissy (Houston's mother) and the Houston family ... it was a matter of public or private as it was this is my daughter, this is my sister, this is my mother, this is my friend and we want to do this with dignity."

Following Saturday's service, Houston is expected to be laid to rest at Fair View Cemetery in Westfield, NJ, next to her father, who was buried there nine years ago.

Houston died at the Beverly Hills Hilton Saturday at the age of 48. Her cause of death continues to be under investigation.

leahc@dose.ca

entry.title: 2012 Grammy Awards - Best and Worst Moments

link.Abstract: It's music's biggest -- and longest -- night. Adele, Foo Fighters, Whitney Houston and more made for some of the most memorable moments of the 54th Annual Grammy Awards.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars. Typically, though, they're in the audience -- collecting more trophies than their Versace-clad arms can carry. That was certainly true of Sunday's edition -- with the likes of Adele, Kanye West and the Foo Fighters being lauded. But there was a heavy note to this year's show, broadcast the day after Whitney Houston's passing. The six-time Grammy winner was remembered throughout the evening, but that didn't stop the 54th Annual Grammy Awards from being the marathon, three and a half hour party it always is. Check out some of the highlights.
--Leah Collins/Dose.ca

But there was a heavy note to this year's show, broadcast the day after Whitney Houston's passing. The six-time Grammy winner was remembered throughout the evenin
